sentence: Equities gave back gains on Wednesday and ended lower after the release of a US tax reform plan.

Positive earnings from United Technologies ( UTX ) helped keep the blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average afloat for most of the session, although a late-session extension of losses in Apple (APPL) weighed.
Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Gary Cohn, an economic adviser to President Donald Trump, unveiled the tax reform package that includes a slash in the corporate rate to 15%.
It's being billed by the government as the biggest ever individual and business cut in US history.
Cohn said the changes are about growing the US economy and creating jobs, although full details will be released at a later date.
The plan was also lacking specifics about the tax rate at which companies like Apple that are holding profits offshore would be able to repatriate the funds.
Stocks have been underpinned in gains this week by positive quarterly earnings releases from heavyweight firms.
On Wednesday, the positive sentiment mostly continued until late in the day, although Boeing ( BA ) and Procter & Gamble ( PG ) weighed on the Dow with misses.
Twitter ( TWTR ) and Wyndham Worldwide ( WYN ) were some of the day's best movers on upbeat financial reports.

On a busy day for Washington news, investors were also digesting reports that Trump is poised to sign an executive order to pull out of the North American Free Trade Agreement, days after the US announced plans to hit Canadian softwood lumber imports with heavy tariffs.
Telecoms led gains on the S&P 500, rising 1.3% as the US Federal Communications Commission proposed overturning 2015 net neutrality rules imposed during the Obama administration.

Verizon ( VZ ) ended 1.4% higher while AT&T (T) gained 1.3%

Thursday's calendar picks up with the initial weekly jobless claims, the March goods trade balance and durable goods orders due at 8:30 a.m.
Advance March reads on retail and wholesale sales will also be released at 8:30 a.m. while March pending home sales are due at 10 a.m.
The April Kansas City Fed Manufacturing Index is due at 11 a.m.

Here's where the markets stood by the close:

(+) AKBA (+33.4%) To receive $865 million from expanded collaboration with Otsuka on anaemia drug

(+) APTI (+4.4%) Upgraded at JP Morgan to overweight from neutral, PT raised 32%

(-) GFI (-3.7%) March quarter gold production fell to 497,000 ounces from 515,000 in the year-ago period
